text: What's going on Vagabuddies? And welcome back.
Right now we are in Toronto, Canada at Buffer Festival.
Last night we screened East of Eden to a live audience at the Elkin Theatre.
We're super happy to share our film with you...
all of you around the world right now.
We're going to be releasing a behind-the-scenes of the whole experience of Butter Festival
But what we want to do now that the video is online is
give you a little bit of background on to the meaning behind the film because there's a lot going on there.
It's definitely a departure from what we've made before.
It's a narrative, a short fictional film.
So if you haven't watched it, stop what you're doing
and watch East of Eden first.
For those of you who have seen it,
let's get into the meaning behind the story.
This is pretty much like a director's cut.
We wanted to sit down with you and have an informal chat
about the symbolism behind the film, how we did it.
First and foremost, we wanted to do something completely different
from our normal travel vlogs and our travel tips, and
we wanted to try to push ourselves creatively and cinematically
to do something that we have never done before.
In order to do that we reached out to my good friend Carlos Mason who is a cinematographer.
We went to high school together and his good friend Shelby Menzer.
Basically, they helped us capture East of Eden in a way that we wouldn't have been able to do on our own.
Obviously, we're on motorcycles for almost six days to capture the entire film.
But it was kind of like a homage to
the Eastern Sierra Nevada and a homage to the place that we grew up,
but in a way that touches on some of the themes that are
affecting the world in 2017.
It was really a marriage of two different ideas we had.
Alex was really wanted to go do something in the Sierra Nevada.
He's also really wanted to do something about motorcycles.
We both did, and motorcycles really are a thing that brings both of us together,
even when we fight and argue as brothers do.
I personally wanted to do something that was speaking to the division around the world right now
and how travel can be a unifying force.
To combat that division, it can be a bridge between different cultures.
We founded Vagabrothers on the premise that travel could create a meaningful conversation
between people of different cultures
by basically teaching people to appreciate the differences between us.
That's something that we realize in 2017
is not just important between cultures, but within them,
especially here in the United States where there are red states those blue states.
There're people who are not talking to each other because of politics,
especially in.. down to the familial level between parents and their kids and
between brothers and sisters.
We really decided to take our idea and try to bring it down to the most personal level.
In the movie, we play fictional brothers, kind of exaggerated versions of ourselves
that don't talk, and we kind of use the brothers to symbolize America as a whole, which we say in the film
are like family members who no longer talk.
This is a theme
that's happening everywhere across the world.. the urban and rural divide and how
the community within a country is just being drawn further and further apart as
cities grow closer and closer together.
It feels like the rural areas of many countries are kind of slipping away
from their counterparts, their brothers and sisters in the city.
That was one of the themes during the film, and that's kind of the setup to the
next part of the film, which is kind of the first movement, if you will, on the journey back to nature.
That was a really exciting place for us to film the..
the second section, the second act is in the Mojave Desert and California.
A lot of people when they think of California, they think of palm trees and beaches,
and although a lot of California is that,
there's this whole other side to California, east side... East of Eden, if you will, and that's
kind of what we played off of for the titling,
and I'll let you take that away because I know that you love
John Steinbeck, the author of East of Eden.  So, please.
East of Eden book by John Steinbeck.
He is California's most famous writer.
He really came into promise in 1930s during the Great Depression.
East of Eden is a story about two brothers,
kind of based loosely on the on the story of Cain and Abel
and the book of Genesis.
The story started there with the idea that
when you think of California, people think of this Eden.. this coastal Eden.
But there's another side to it.  That kind of plays into
the idea of people who live in the city, such as the characters, trying to discover
what else there is beyond what they can.. what they usually associate with their home,  California.
The desert is such an integral part of what California is, and especially in this part of the Mojave Desert.
There's a lot of abandoned, kind of ghost towns.
There was a mining boom in the 1800s, and tons of people moved there trying to strike it rich.
California has always.. it is the Golden State. It was really founded on this belief of being able to change your destiny
and to strike it rich.
And so there are tons of these mining towns.. kind of boom towns.
When the mining dried up, the people moved away,
but they left kind of this skeleton of civilization, and
that was a really interesting
kind of.. in the in the film, you start in the urban hive, if you will, where everyone's uber connected
and you're on your phone. Isolated, connected yet isolated....
part of the city, but feelings of being alone, and the transition
through kind of this skeletal  settlement, like the bones of civilization.
What happens when people move away and the cities start to decay?
For me that was like
cinematically one of the most interesting parts of the film.
I really enjoyed capturing it, even though we were spending multiple days in
110 degree Fahrenheit heat on our motorcycles, riding around through the desert
trying to get to the places to capture those moments.
The places that we visited in this film are the places that are usually the red part of California.
In the last election, they voted for Donald Trump while the majority of California
voted for Hillary Clinton is more liberal.
But to consider California as a monolithic whole is false.
There are all types of people within California, and
this part of the state is often overlooked.
In the United States people often refer to everything between New York and
Los Angeles as the flyover States, which is really unfortunate.
So what we were trying to show is that this place,
which usually we have sped past on the way to Mammoth Mountain, which is the big ski resort in
California, we wanted to really go on motorbike and go slowly and go to every single
there and see what the stories are.
And the stories that we found in these places are really
telling as a whole of the United States.
Randsburg an old mining town, which was abandoned.
This is kind of a way of nodding towards the economic dislocation
that's happening in the Rust Belt of the United States....
Old factory towns that have been displaced by globalization
and automation and just the general shifting patterns of the economy.
This is happening all around the world, and you can't just ignore that.
You have to be able to...
If you're living in a part of the world where jobs are prospering, and the future looks bright, we felt
it was important to go to other parts of the country where that is not such an optimistic future.
As we continue to travel north,
we leave kind of the ghost towns, and we pass another reminder of
the history in our country.
During the Second World War, we had
Japanese American citizens who were American citizens and
were forcibly relocated from their homes across the United States and put into a
war internment camp in
the Eastern Sierra of California
in this mountain range, basically.
Manzanar was a war relocation center where
American citizens were forcibly removed from their homes and forced to live under guard.
It was kind of like an American concentration camp, and
so us visiting that
and the lines that are spoken
during that scene about perspective
was a super powerful moment in the film and one that we felt
was necessary to kind of give you all a bit of backstory on so that that scene really
resonates the way that we wanted it to resonate.
Moving past all these layers of California's history and using California
as an analogy for the United States as a whole,
we feel that one of the most
enduring legacies of the last hundred years is the national park system, which was basically
founded from the ideas of a guy named John Muir.
He was a Scottish conservationist.
He moved to the United States,
and he fell in love with the Sierra Nevada Mountains and Yosemite Valley.
He was kind of the first mover for the national parks system
and the conservationist movement  that saved all of these natural places
and places that we as Americans and the entire world
cherish and look at.  And just look at your Instagram feed.  How many
thousands of photos have you seen from Yosemite Valley
and from all of the national parks around the United States?
Gooing there is kind of the moment when we
come together as brothers and as a nation.
Our goal with this film was to
unify.. to try to bridge divides between different communities.
Our goal was not to try to tell people how to think or what they should believe in.
Instead, we really wanted to
try to just empathize and try to find common ground.
If you notice, there's a theme in this film of water.  We start off...
We essentially trace the Los Angeles aqueduct
from the city to the mountains where the water comes from,
and the climactic moment is us going into a lake.  But before that
we go by California City, which is...
was a really idealistic
development in the 1960s that was supposed to be a city as large as Los Angeles to rival it in size.
It is actually the third largest city in California by space, but it's abandoned and it's now this desert,
and it shows what happens if we didn't have water.
But this water ultimately comes from the communities we were visiting.
It comes from the Owens Valley.
And that was kind of our way of showing how cities are
inherently dependent on the rural areas that surround them.
They don't exist in isolation.
So it was kind of a way of trying to show the characters being humbled by their dependency on their neighbors
And kind of having a thread to go through all the different parts of California,
leading to the climactic moment of a sort of baptism of a spiritual renewal
by washing yourself in these waters as you would in a religious ceremony
because as John Muir has said as many American
philosophers over the years have said, "Nature is the sacred religion of the United States; it is mountains, rivers
forests that are our cathedrals, are our chapels."
It's where we go to be one with the universe, and that's a thread that you hear from
Henry David Thoreau, to Ralph Waldo Emerson ,John Muir and
that is kind of what we were trying to provide as a solution,
not that you should think this way or you should think that way,
but just trying to find something that people in rural communities and urban settings
could come together around, which is this idea that nature is
our special place. Nature is sacred. It's the undertone of
conservationism that we believe in, something that we hold very dearly, and something that I think is universal.
There's the line in the film that says,  "Eventually we all must come down from the mountain,"  and taking that
perspective that we've gained through this journey
back with us into the city and
trying to integrate that into our lives and
to remember that we don't exist in isolation,
that we're dependent on each other, and that at the end of the day, we are brothers and sisters,
regardless of our beliefs or our viewpoints.
That's kind of the takeaway from East of Eden.
The whole process of pre-production, of
production and post-production on East of Eden has been a huge learning curve.
It's been super enlightening.
It's been challenging. It's been fun.
It's been a journey, just like the film was a journey,
and we're so grateful to be able to A: do it with friends.
Thank you, Carlos Mason. Thank you, Shelby. Thank you, Dillon. Thank you, Ariana.
All the people.  Thank you ,Carrie Rad
and our Aunt Jean, everyone who helped make this
film a reality and help us tell stories in a new way.
I just want to say thank you all for the support.
And thank you to Buffer Festival for
giving us the impetus to make this video.
A great thing about a film fest is that.. although it's not competitive in nature,
it is something that pushes you to try to make something that looks good on the big screen.
That is really something that we've never done before.
It was a step towards us becoming more of a professional
production team and something that we're hoping to carry with us forward
as we continue to up the ante on our production level.
If you've never been to Buffer Festival before, it's extremely fun.
I highly encourage you to come here next year.
Hopefully, we'll be premiering something else awesome next year in Toronto.
Let us know your thoughts in the comments section.  If you enjoyed
this video, if you enjoyed the film,
please go give those big thumbs- up, share with all of your friends.  And in the meantime,
